channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Nepal to Establish Weather Warning System After Hiking Disaster
item.description: As the death toll rose to 31, dozens of people were thought to be still missing after a massive snowstorm and avalanche in the Himalayas.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Hong Kong Protesters Retake Street, Defying Government
item.description: The police, who had gained control of the street in the Mong Kok district only hours before, retreated to avoid a confrontation.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: U.S. Commander Reports Heavy ISIS Losses in Syrian City of Kobani
item.description: The head of the United States Central Command indicated that even if the Islamic State managed to take Kobani, the victory would be costly to the group.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: Nigeria Said to Declare Cease-Fire With Boko Haram Militants
item.description: Nigerian news outlets reported that a truce came amid talks with the militants over the release of more than 200 girls kidnapped from a rural school months ago.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Ad Featuring Pandas Behaving Badly Quickly Goes Extinct
item.description: A public service advertisement depicting pandas as ill-behaved louts on holiday in Australia — tossing litter, painting graffiti and barging over pedestrians with arms full of shopping bags — did not go over well in China.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Drone Stunt at Belgrade Soccer Match Stirs Ethnic Tensions
item.description: An Albanian nationalist banner flown over a stadium in the Serbian capital ignited a brawl on the field and went on to provoke a full-scale diplomatic incident.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Stefan Mitrovic, a defender on Serbia's soccer team, pulled down an Albanian banner carried by a drone flying above his team's game with Albania on Tuesday.

item.title: Venezuela Gets U.N. Seat; Turkey Is Denied
item.description: After two rounds of voting at the General Assembly, the five new rotating members will be Angola, Malaysia, New Zealand, Spain and Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: In Layers of Gear, Offering Healing Hand to Ebola Patients in Liberia
item.description: Doctors offer Ebola patients simple comforts, like feeding them or cleaning them up. But they also try to restrain their own impulses, because old habits might not be safe.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By SHERI FINK
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Steven Hatch carried Blessing Gea, 9, into the high-risk ward.

item.title: Kerry Flies Commercial After Jet Breaks Down in Vienna
item.description: A problem with his Air Force jet prompted Secretary of State John Kerry to rush to the airport Thursday morning for a commercial flight back to Washington.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: China Said to Pull the Strings in Hong Kong Crackdown
item.description: China has played a hidden role in directing the broad outlines of the response to pro-democracy protests, current and former officials from both governments say.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Protesters faced police in the Mong Kok district of Hong Kong on Friday.

item.title: At Least 14 Killed at Pop Concert in South Korea, Officials Say
item.description: A group of concertgoers plunged 66 feet after the steel grids at the top of a ventilation platform collapsed.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Yonhap, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The scene after a pop concert in Seongnam City, South Korea, where a ventilation grate collapsed, dropping 25 people into the parking area below and killing at least 14.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Despite Poverty Efforts, China Still Faces Income Gap
item.description: China says that it has lifted 660 million people out of poverty and that more than 90 percent of poverty alleviation in recent decades has occurred in China. Other research shows income inequality is severe.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A boy peeks outside his home in this makeshift residential area for migrant workers in Beijing.

item.title: At Pistorius Hearing, Fervent Arguments Over Punishment
item.description: On the fifth day of hearings, the track star’s lawyer made an impassioned plea to keep him out of prison, while the prosecution urged a 10-year sentence.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Crony Communism in China
item.description: Xi Jinping is going after corruption because it threatens the party's future. But his actions threaten the party now.
item.dc:creator: By MINXIN PEI

item.title: Genocide Trial Begins for Khmer Rouge Leaders
item.description: The two defendants, who were sentenced to life in prison in a separate proceeding, face broader charges on crimes against humanity this time.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By JULIA WALLACE

item.title: Leaders of China and Japan Are Likely to Meet, Briefly, for First Time
item.description: The meeting between Xi Jinping and Shinzo Abe is expected on the sidelines of the APEC summit next month, Japanese officials said.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Bermuda Prepares for Hurricane Gonzalo
item.description: Hurricane Gonzalo, a Category 4 storm, is one of the strongest on record to menace the island.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Israeli Troops Are Suspected in Shooting of a Teenager
item.description: The military said it would investigate reports that soldiers killed a 13-year-old Palestinian during a confrontation near the West Bank city of Ramallah.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Serbia Honors Putin While Keeping Its Eyes on Ties to the West
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin’s visit to Belgrade this week has highlighted a balancing act for Serbia, which wants to join the European Union but not the bloc’s sanctions against Russia.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, center, standing next to Serbia’s president, Tomislav Nikolic, at a military parade in Belgrade full of soldiers and fighter jets.

item.title: Narendra Modi, India’s Leader, Moves to Reshape Labor Rules
item.description: The changes are aimed at increasing manufacturing, but critics said they did not go far enough.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: A Sona Koyo Steering Systems factory south of New Delhi. Prime Minister Narendra Modi unveiled changes in labor regulations.

item.title: Bloc in Europe Starts to Balk Over Austerity
item.description: Many of the largest European countries, including France and Italy, are now rebelling against the German gospel of belt-tightening and calling for more radical steps to reverse their slumping fortunes.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY and JACK EWING
item.media:description: François Hollande of France and Angela Merkel of Germany on Thursday at a meeting of European and Asian heads of state.

item.title: In Exodus From Israel to Germany, a Young Nation’s Fissures Show
item.description: A Facebook post this month extolling the lower cost of living in Berlin has revived a raw debate in Israel, with pundits and politicians denouncing those who want to leave as anti-Zionist traitors.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two Israelis, one supporting migration to Germany and one opposing it, argued in Tel Aviv. Berlin has a lower cost of living and a growing community of Israelis.

item.title: Kerry Flies Commercial After Jet Breaks Down in Iran
item.description: A problem with his Air Force jet prompted Secretary of State John Kerry to rush to the airport Thursday morning for a commercial flight back to Washington.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Pursuing a Calling That Leads to West Africa
item.description: Dr. Steven Hatch of the University of Massachusetts medical school explains what led him to volunteer at an Ebola clinic in Suakoko, Liberia.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN HATCH

item.title: World Briefing: Democratic Republic of Congo: Rebels Attack Town
item.description: Rebels crept into houses and attacked civilians, killing at least 30 people around the eastern town of Beni, the mayor, Nyonyi Bwana Kawa, said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
